metadata.case_name: Pannalal Jayasora & Ors. v. State of West Bengal

facts.text: On 16th March 1993, just before midnight, explosions in Bow Bazar area, Calcutta, at 267, 266 and 268 A, B.B. Ganguly Street resulted in total demolition of one building and partial demolition of two adjacent buildings. Large number of people trapped, 69 deaths, human limbs scattered.
FIR lodged at Bow Bazar Police Station under Sections 120B, 436, 302, 307, 326 IPC and Sections 3 and 5 of Explosive Substances Act, 1908.
Commissioner of Police set up special investigating team due to seriousness.
Further explosion on 18.3.1993 during rescue operations; exploded bomb handed to police by Military Officer; pay loader picked gunny bag containing 22 live bombs, later defused.
Materials seized from site showed nitro-glycerin explosives involved.
Pannalal Jayasora arrested on 29.3.1993, Mohd. Gulzar on 13.5.1993; their confessional statements recorded by Judicial Magistrates (PWs 81 and 82).
Some accused identified in Test Identification Parades.
On 11.6.1993, Commissioner of Police concluded TADA provisions applicable; sanction accorded.
Calcutta High Court quashed sanction and cognizance under TADA; SC allowed prosecution appeal and directed Designated Court to proceed (State of West Bengal v. Mohd. Khalid, 1995 1 SCC 684).
Designated Court framed charges under 120B, 436/34, 302/34 IPC, Ss.3,5 Explosive Act, Ss.3(2)(i), 3(3) TADA.
165 witnesses examined; star witnesses PW40 Md. Sabir Natu, PW67 Santosh Hazra, PW68 Kristin Chow Kittu proved conspiracy.
Designated Court convicted under 120B IPC, Ss.3,5 Explosive Act, 3(2)(i),3(3) TADA r/w 34 IPC; acquitted under 302/34, 436/34 IPC.

Sentences: RI life + fine Rs.3000 for 3(2)(i) TADA r/w34; RI 5 yrs + Rs.500 for 3(3) TADA; RI 10 yrs + Rs.1000 for S.3 Explosive Act; RI 1 yr + Rs.300 for S.5 Explosive Act; RI life + Rs.3000 for 120B IPC.
PW40 saw accused carrying gunny bags, mixing explosives, manufacturing bombs at 267 BB Ganguly St; saw Rashid ask Pannalal to prepare bombs.
PW67, PW68 saw Rashid with Pannalal; heard discussions on preparing large number of bombs due to Bombay riots, for use if Hindus attack Muslims.
Confessions of Pannalal and Gulzar: urgency for bombs due to riots, to protect Muslims.

legal_issues.text: Whether evidence of star witnesses PW40,67,68 is reliable and establishes conspiracy and preparation of bombs.
Whether confessional statements under S.164 CrPC of co-accused Pannalal and Gulzar are voluntary, true and admissible against appellants.
Whether non-examination of certain witnesses like Nausad and Osman renders prosecution case suspect.
Whether acts constitute criminal conspiracy under S.120B IPC.
Whether provisions of TADA Act applicable, i.e., whether acts were terrorist acts to strike terror and affect communal harmony.
Whether acts fall under Ss.3,5 Explosive Substances Act.
Whether defence of private defence applicable, i.e., bombs prepared for self-protection against possible Hindu attack post-Bombay riots.

petitioner_arguments.text: Star witnesses PW40,67,68 have doubtful antecedents, rowdy elements under police thumb; evidence full of fallacies, embellished, delayed recording without explanation.
Non-examination of independent witnesses like Nausad (owner), Osman; renders prosecution suspect; no reliable conspiracy evidence.
Explosions accidental; confessions retracted, obtained by terror/threat; not substantive evidence; S.30 Evidence Act not applicable without other convincing evidence.
Bombs for self-protection in private defence against possible Hindu attack post-Bombay riots; police ineffective there; not to spread terror; TADA not applicable.
No material accused caused explosion; deceased accused may have; no mens rea for Explosive Act S.3.
S.10 Evidence Act not applicable to post-arrest confessions.

respondent_arguments.text: Star witnesses reliable; presence natural as locals involved in satta; delay due to chaos, rescue priority; relatives of PW68 died.
Non-examination not fatal; quality over quantity; Nausad/Osman not material.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Habeeb Mohammad v. State of Hyderabad AIR 1954 SC 51

respondent_arguments.text: Confessions voluntary, recorded by Magistrates after warnings; retraction afterthought; greater credibility under TADA; corroborate other evidence.
Conspiracy proved by circumstances, eyewitnesses, confessions; agreement to manufacture bombs illegally to strike terror post-riots.
Terrorist act under TADA: intent to strike terror, affect communal harmony; large quantity explosives/bombs not for self-defence.
Possession/control of explosives with unlawful intent under Explosive Act; constructive liability even if not direct causers.

court_reasoning.text: Evidence of PW40,67,68 reliable after scrutiny; natural presence, delay explained by rescue chaos; identifies accused, overhears bomb prep talks linked to riots.
Non-examination of some witnesses not adverse; prosecution selects material ones; quality matters.
Criminal conspiracy under S.120B proved by circumstantial/direct evidence of agreement to manufacture bombs illegally; overt acts in preparation; no need for accomplishment.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Essence is agreement; proved by witnesses/confessions.

court_reasoning.text: Confessions voluntary/true per Magistrates; admissible under S.30 Evidence Act as corroborative after independent evidence; S.10 not applicable post-arrest.
Terrorist act under TADA: preparation/possession of bombs to strike terror, affect communal harmony; not self-defence as no apprehension of attack.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Per se illegal; intent to terrorise.

court_reasoning.text: Explosive Act Ss.3/5 applicable via possession/unlawful use; conviction sustainable under S.4 if needed, but sentence unaffected.
Private defence not available: no reasonable apprehension; right commences only on apprehension; no time lapse issue.

holdings.text: Eyewitness evidence reliable; establishes presence and bomb preparation.
Confessions voluntary, used corroboratively under S.30 Evidence Act.
Criminal conspiracy under S.120B IPC proved.
TADA Ss.3(2)(i), 3(3) applicable as terrorist acts.
Convictions under 120B IPC, Ss.3,5 Explosive Act upheld; acquittal under 302/34, 436/34 IPC justified.
No private defence; appeals by accused dismissed.

precedents_cited.case_name: State of West Bengal v. Mohd. Khalid
precedents_cited.relevance: Reversed HC quashing TADA sanction; directed trial.

precedents_cited.case_name: Habeeb Mohammad v. State of Hyderabad
precedents_cited.relevance: Prosecution not bound to examine all witnesses; no adverse inference.

precedents_cited.case_name: Bhagwan Swarup Lal v. State of Maharashtra
precedents_cited.relevance: Conspiracy proof by circumstantial evidence; essence is agreement.

precedents_cited.case_name: Kashmira Singh v. State of Madhya Pradesh
precedents_cited.relevance: Approach to co-accused confession under S.30 Evidence Act.
S.30 confession weak evidence, needs corroboration.

precedents_cited.case_name: State of Gujarat v. Mohd. Atik
precedents_cited.relevance: Post-arrest statements not under S.10 Evidence Act.
S.10 limited to statements during subsistence of conspiracy.

precedents_cited.case_name: C. Bahri v. State of Bihar
precedents_cited.relevance: No overt act needed if conspiracy to commit offence.

precedents_cited.case_name: Yogendra Morarji v. State of Gujarat
precedents_cited.relevance: Private defence commences on reasonable apprehension.

statutes_cited.name: Indian Penal Code, 1860
statutes_cited.relevance: Criminal conspiracy proved; acquittal under murder/arson upheld.

statutes_cited.name: Explosive Substances Act, 1908
statutes_cited.relevance: Unlawful manufacture/possession/use of explosives; conviction upheld.

statutes_cited.name: Terrorist and Disruptive Activities (Prevention) Act, 1987
statutes_cited.relevance: Terrorist acts to strike terror/affect communal harmony; convictions upheld.

statutes_cited.name: Indian Evidence Act, 1872
statutes_cited.relevance: Co-conspirator statements limited; confessions voluntary, corroborative.

outcome.summary: Supreme Court dismissed appeals by accused-appellants challenging convictions and sentences under 120B IPC, Ss.3,5 Explosive Act, Ss.3(2)(i),3(3) TADA r/w 34 IPC; dismissed State appeal against acquittal under 302/34, 436/34 IPC. All seven appeals dismissed.

key_quotes.text: No religion propagates terrorism or hatred. Love for all is the basic foundation on which almost all religions are founded.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Opening observation on communal disharmony context.

key_quotes.text: The essence of a criminal conspiracy is the unlawful combination and ordinarily the offence is complete when the combination is framed.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.relevance: Defines key element of conspiracy offence.

key_quotes.text: Preparation and storage of bombs are per se illegal acts.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Rejects self-defence plea for TADA applicability.

key_quotes.text: The cover of self-protection when pierced unravels a sinister design to unleash terror.
key_quotes.speaker: court
